That was the answer I got!" 
SHORTLY AFTER nine o'clock that evening, Wey- rother drove with his plans to Kutiizov's quar- ters where the council of war was to be held. All the commanders of columns were sum- moned to the commander in chief's and with the exception of Prince Bagrati6n, who de- clined to come, were all there at the appointed time. 
Weyrother, who was in full control of the proposed battle, by his eagerness and briskness presented a marked contrast to the dissatisfied and
